clean_story:
False confidence. The gap between skill and belief.

The "illusion of mastery" happens when someone thinks they’ve learned something—but haven’t.
Like reading a recipe and assuming you can bake the cake without practicing.

Studies show people overestimate their knowledge after passive learning.
Example: Students who reread notes feel "prepared," but tests reveal weak recall.
The brain confuses familiarity (seeing info repeatedly) with understanding (applying it).
Real mastery requires struggle—mistakes, corrections, repetition.
Like a pianist who plays scales slowly, not just listens to them.
The illusion fades when tested.

Dunning-Kruger effect.
Desirable difficulties.
The expertise paradox.
